name: Datastore
description:
The gcloud.datastore object allows you to interact with Google Cloud Datastore.

To learn more about Datastore, read the Google Cloud Datastore Concepts Overview

examples.caption:
The Datastore Emulator

gcloud SDK not supported

As of this release, the Datastore emulator that is part of the gcloud SDK is not compatible with gcloud-node. We use gRPC as our transport layer, while the gcloud SDK's Datastore emulator does not support gRPC.

Use gcd.sh directly

For now, you must use the gcd.sh script. When you run ./gcd start [datastore], you will see the following printed: 
 
If you are using a library that supports the DATASTORE_EMULATOR_HOST 
environment variable, run: 
export DATASTORE_EMULATOR_HOST=localhost:8080
Set that environment variable and your localhost Datastore will automatically be used. You can also pass this address in manually with apiEndpoint.
Additionally, DATASTORE_PROJECT_ID is recognized. If you have this set, you don't need to provide a projectId.

Retrieving Records

Records, called "entities" in Datastore, are retrieved by using a key. The key is more than a numeric identifier, it is a complex data structure that can be used to model relationships. The simplest key has a string kind value, and either a numeric id value, or a string name value. A single record can be retrieved with datastore/key and datastore#get.

Querying Records

Create a query with datastore#createQuery.
examples.code: var query = datastore.createQuery('Company');

examples.caption: Multiple records can be found that match criteria with datastore/query#filter.
examples.code: query.filter('location', 'CA');

examples.caption: Records can also be ordered with datastore/query#order.
examples.code: query.order('name');

examples.caption: The number of records returned can be specified with datastore/query#limit.
examples.code: query.limit(5);

examples.caption: Records' key structures can also be queried with datastore/query#hasAncestor.
examples.code:
var ancestorKey = datastore.key(['ParentCompany', 'Alphabet']);

query.hasAncestor(ancestorKey);

examples.caption: Run the query with datastore#runQuery.

Paginating Records

Imagine building a website that allows a user to sift through hundreds of their contacts. You'll likely want to only display a subset of these at once, so you set a limit.

Creating Records

New entities can be created and persisted with datastore#save. The entitiy must have a key to be saved. If you don't specify an identifier for the key, one is generated for you. We will create a key with a name identifier, "Google".
We can verify the data was saved by using datastore#get.
If we want to update this record, we can modify the data object and re- save it.

Deleting Records

Entities can be removed from Datastore by passing the entity's key object to datastore#delete.

Transactions

Complex logic can be wrapped in a transaction with datastore#transaction. All queries and updates run within the transaction will be applied when the done function is called.

params.name: options.apiEndpoint
params.description: • Override the default API endpoint used to reach Datastore. This is useful for connecting to your local Datastore server (usually "http://localhost:8080").

methods.name: double
methods.description: Helper function to get a Datastore Double object.

examples.code: var threeDouble = gcloud.datastore.double(3.0);

methods.name: geoPoint
methods.description: Helper function to get a Datastore Geo Point object.

methods.name: int
methods.description: Helper function to get a Datastore Integer object.

examples.code: var sevenInteger = gcloud.datastore.int(7);

methods.name: MORE_RESULTS_AFTER_CURSOR
methods.description:
This is one of three values which may be returned from datastore#runQuery, transaction#runQuery, and datastore/query#run as info.moreResults.

There may be more results after the specified end cursor.

methods.name: MORE_RESULTS_AFTER_LIMIT
methods.description:
This is one of three values which may be returned from datastore#runQuery, transaction#runQuery, and datastore/query#run as info.moreResults.

There may be more results after the specified limit.

methods.name: NO_MORE_RESULTS
methods.description:
This is one of three values which may be returned from datastore#runQuery, transaction#runQuery, and datastore/query#run as info.moreResults.

There are no more results left to query for.

methods.name: createQuery
methods.description: Create a query for the specified kind. See datastore/query for all of the available methods.

examples.code: var query = datastore.createQuery('Company');

methods.name: key
methods.description:
Helper to create a Key object, scoped to the instance's namespace by default.

You may also specify a configuration object to define a namespace and path.

examples.caption: Create an incomplete key with a kind value of Company.
examples.code: var key = datastore.key('Company');

examples.caption: Create a complete key with a kind value of Company and id 123.
examples.code: var key = datastore.key(['Company', 123]);

examples.caption: Create a complete key with a kind value of Company and name Google. Note: id is used for numeric identifiers and name is used otherwise.
examples.code: var key = datastore.key(['Company', 'Google']);

examples.caption: Create a complete key from a provided namespace and path.

params.name: options
params.description: • Key path. To specify or override a namespace, you must use an object here to explicitly state it.

returns.description: A newly created Key from the options given.

examples.code: var incompleteKey = datastore.key(['Company']);

examples.caption: The following call will create 100 new IDs from the Company kind, which exists under the default namespace.
examples.code: datastore.allocateIds(incompleteKey, 100, function(err, keys) {});

examples.caption: Or, if you're using a transaction object.

You may prefer to create IDs from a non-default namespace by providing an incomplete key with a namespace. Similar to the previous example, the call below will create 100 new IDs, but from the Company kind that exists under the "ns-test" namespace.

params.name: callback.err
params.description: • An error returned while making this request

methods.name: delete
methods.description: Delete all entities identified with the specified key(s).

examples.code:
var key = datastore.key(['Company', 123]);
datastore.delete(key, function(err, apiResp) {});

examples.caption: Or, if you're using a transaction object.
Delete multiple entities at once.

params.name: callback.err
params.description: • An error returned while making this request

methods.name: get
methods.description: Retrieve the entities identified with the specified key(s) in the current transaction. Get operations require a valid key to retrieve the key-identified entity from Datastore.

examples.caption: Get a single entity.
examples.code:
var key = datastore.key(['Company', 123]);

datastore.get(key, function(err, entity) {});

examples.caption: Or, if you're using a transaction object.
Get multiple entities at once with a callback.
Or, get the entities as a readable object stream.
Here's how you would update the value of an entity with the help of the save method.

params.name: options.consistency
params.description: • Specify either strong or eventual. If not specified, default values are chosen by Datastore for the operation. Learn more about strong and eventual consistency here.

params.name: callback.err
params.description: • An error returned while making this request

params.name: callback.entity
params.description: • The entity object(s) which match the provided keys.

exceptions.description: If at least one Key object is not provided.

methods.name: insert
methods.description: Maps to datastore#save, forcing the method to be insert.

methods.name: runQuery
methods.description:
Datastore allows you to query entities by kind, filter them by property filters, and sort them by a property name. Projection and pagination are also supported.

If you provide a callback, the query is run, and the results are returned as the second argument to your callback. A third argument may also exist, which is a query object that uses the end cursor from the previous query as the starting cursor for the next query. You can pass that object back to this method to see if more results exist.

You may also omit the callback to this function to trigger streaming mode.

See below for examples of both approaches.

examples.caption: Where you see transaction, assume this is the context that's relevant to your use, whether that be a Datastore or a Transaction object.
examples.code:
var query = datastore.createQuery('Lion');

datastore.runQuery(query, function(err, entities, info) {});

examples.caption: Or, if you're using a transaction object.
If you omit the callback, you will get the matching entities in a readable object stream.
If you anticipate many results, you can end a stream early to prevent unnecessary processing and API requests.
A keys-only query returns just the keys of the result entities instead of the entities themselves, at lower latency and cost.

params.name: options.consistency
params.description: • Specify either strong or eventual. If not specified, default values are chosen by Datastore for the operation. Learn more about strong and eventual consistency here.

params.name: callback
params.description: • The callback function. If omitted, a readable stream instance is returned.

params.name: callback.err
params.description: • An error returned while making this request

params.name: callback.info.endCursor
params.description: • Use this in a follow-up query to begin from where these results ended.

params.name: callback.info.moreResults
params.description:
• Datastore responds with one of:
    • datastore#MORE_RESULTS_AFTER_LIMIT: There may be more results after the specified limit.
    • datastore#MORE_RESULTS_AFTER_CURSOR: There may be more results after the specified end cursor.
    • datastore#NO_MORE_RESULTS: There are no more results.

methods.name: save
methods.description:
Insert or update the specified object(s). If a key is incomplete, its associated object is inserted and the original Key object is updated to contain the generated ID.

This method will determine the correct Datastore method to execute (upsert, insert, or update) by using the key(s) provided. For example, if you provide an incomplete key (one without an ID), the request will create a new entity and have its ID automatically assigned. If you provide a complete key, the entity will be updated with the data specified.

By default, all properties are indexed. To prevent a property from being included in all indexes, you must supply an entity's data property as an array. See below for an example.

examples.caption: Save a single entity. Notice that we are providing an incomplete key. After saving, the original Key object used to save will be updated to contain the path with its generated ID.

Save a single entity using a provided name instead of auto-generated ID. Here we are providing a key with name instead of an ID. After saving, the original Key object used to save will be updated to contain the path with the name instead of a generated ID.

Save a single entity with a provided namespace. Namespaces allow for multitenancy. To read more about this, see [the Datastore docs on key concepts](https://goo.gl/M1LUAu). Here we are providing a key with namespace.

Save different types of data, including ints, doubles, dates, booleans, blobs, and lists. Notice that we are providing an incomplete key. After saving, the original Key object used to save will be updated to contain the path with its generated ID.
To specify an excludeFromIndexes value for a Datastore entity, pass in an array for the key's data.
Save multiple entities at once.
Explicitly attempt to 'insert' a specific entity.

params.name: entities.data
params.description: • Data to save with the provided key. If you provide an array of objects, you must use the explicit syntax: name for the name of the property and value for its value. You may also specify an excludeFromIndexes property, set to true or false.

params.name: callback.err
params.description: • An error returned while making this request

methods.name: update
methods.description: Maps to datastore#save, forcing the method to be update.

methods.name: upsert
methods.description: Maps to datastore#save, forcing the method to be upsert.
